The statement, however, that every religion in order to be free from persecution needed to be licensed, is too sweeping.

The general principle of the Roman government in matters of religion

, was toleration, and only those religions which by in anyway taking the ' form of collegia constituted a political danger, or were dangerous to public morality, would be liable to interference. The law therefore

which Dr. Lightfoot speaks of as able to be set in motion was no general
